verses.text: Then what advantage does the Jew have? Or what is the value of circumcision?
verses.comment: Paul begins by addressing the privileges given to the Jewish people, especially concerning the covenant sign of circumcision. He sets the stage for explaining God's plan which embraces both Jews and Gentiles.

verses.text: Much in every way. First, they were entrusted with the words of God.
verses.comment: Paul highlights the honor given to Israel through the revelation of God's words (the Scriptures and the law). This sets a precedent for the importance of both tradition and written word in understanding God’s will.

verses.text: For what if some were unfaithful? Does their unfaithfulness nullify the faithfulness of God?
verses.comment: Human unfaithfulness does not diminish God’s faithfulness. This prepares us for the concept of grace prevailing over human shortcomings.

verses.text: Absolutely not! Let God be true, but everyone a liar; as it is written: 'So that you may be justified in your words and prevail when you are judged.'
verses.comment: Paul quotes the Old Testament to stress God's righteousness and faithfulness, even when humanity fails. The quotes underscore divine justice and veracity.

verses.text: But if our unrighteousness shows God's righteousness, what shall we say? Is God unjust to bring wrath on us? (I speak in a human way.)
verses.comment: Paul anticipates objections. Using a rhetorical question, he rejects the notion that God is unjust for judging sin, even if human sin highlights His righteousness.

verses.text: By no means! For then, how will God judge the world?
verses.comment: Paul stresses the necessity of God's justice, affirming universal judgment. This has eschatological significance, pointing to final judgment.

verses.text: But if through my lie God's truth increases to His glory, why am I still being judged as a sinner?
verses.comment: Paul rebuts the faulty logic that excusing sin for a 'greater good' is permissible. God's glory is not advanced through human wrongdoing.

verses.text: Why not say—as some slanderously claim we do—'Let us do evil so that good may come'? Their condemnation is deserved.
verses.comment: Paul rejects the charge that his gospel permits lawlessness. Sinners will receive just condemnation, hinting at the necessity of grace and transformation.

verses.text: What then? Are we better off? Not at all. For we have already charged that both Jews and Greeks are all under sin.
verses.comment: All humanity is equally in need of redemption, regardless of religious heritage. This universal need for grace ties into the later call to unity in Christ.

verses.text: As it is written: 'None is righteous, no, not one.'
verses.comment: Quoting the Psalms, Paul teaches the universality of sin. This sets the stage for God's action in salvation.

verses.text: 'No one understands; no one seeks for God.'
verses.comment: Scripture reveals that seeking God is initiated by God's grace, not human effort alone—a point crucial in discussing salvation.

verses.text: 'All have turned aside; together they have become worthless; no one does good, not even one.'
verses.comment: Humanity’s fallen state is total. This underscores the need for divine intervention.

verses.text: 'Their throat is an open grave; with their tongues they deceive.' 'The poison of vipers is under their lips.'
verses.comment: Sin corrupts speech and relationships. Paul aggregates various Old Testament descriptions to show both the depth and pervasiveness of sin.

verses.text: 'Their mouth is full of curses and bitterness.'
verses.comment: Paul continues his catalog of human depravity by emphasizing corrupt speech, a recurring biblical motif.

verses.text: 'Their feet are swift to shed blood;'
verses.comment: Sin is not only internal but leads to violence and injustice. Paul highlights social consequences of alienation from God.

verses.text: 'Ruin and misery are in their paths,'
verses.comment: Paul uses prophetic imagery to amplify the destructive nature of sin.

verses.text: 'And the way of peace they have not known.'
verses.comment: A life marked by sin lacks true peace, indicating a need for reconciliation through God's plan.

verses.text: 'There is no fear of God before their eyes.'
verses.comment: The absence of reverence for God is the root of all described depravity. Reverence and worship are foundational to true faith.

verses.text: Now we know that whatever the law says, it speaks to those under the law, so that every mouth may be stopped, and the whole world may be held accountable to God.
verses.comment: All stand guilty before God, both Jew and Gentile, requiring a deeper remedy than law observance—anticipating the role of justification.

verses.text: For by works of the law no human being will be justified in His sight, since through the law comes knowledge of sin.
verses.comment: Law reveals but cannot cure sin. This emphasizes justification by faith, which opens interpretation toward a sacramental understanding where grace is given.

verses.text: But now, apart from the law, God's righteousness has been revealed, being testified by the Law and the Prophets—
verses.comment: Paul connects the gospel directly to Old Testament prophecy, affirming both continuity and fulfillment. Note how law and prophecy together witness to the new work of God.

verses.text: the righteousness of God through faith in Jesus Christ for all who believe. For there is no distinction:
verses.comment: Salvation is by faith in Christ, available to everyone. The passage points to the centrality and universality of Christ, consistent with the united Church’s understanding.

verses.text: for all have sinned and fall short of the glory of God,
verses.comment: A summary statement of universal sinfulness, foundational to understanding the necessity of grace and the work of redemption.

verses.text: and are justified freely by His grace through the redemption that is in Christ Jesus.
verses.comment: Justification is a gift—not earned. The language of 'redemption' invokes sacramental participation in Christ’s saving work and foreshadows a liturgical understanding centered around Christ's sacrifice.

verses.text: God presented Him as a propitiation by His blood, to be received by faith. He did this to demonstrate His righteousness, because in His divine forbearance He had passed over former sins.
verses.comment: Paul uses temple imagery ('propitiation') recalling the mercy seat. Christ’s blood is central, hinting at the sacrificial and ongoing nature of atonement, which points toward liturgical participation.

verses.text: He did this to demonstrate His righteousness at the present time, so that He would be just and the justifier of the one who has faith in Jesus.
verses.comment: Paul shows that God is both perfectly just and merciful, with faith in Jesus as the means of justification. This emphasizes a holistic salvation not by self, but from above.

verses.text: Where then is boasting? It is excluded. By what law? By the law of works? No, but by the law of faith.
verses.comment: Boasting is ruled out. Faith, not works of law, aligns with the entire biblical narrative of grace. True unity in faith leads necessarily to humility and communal unity.

verses.text: For we hold that one is justified by faith apart from works of the law.
verses.comment: Paul clarifies: justification is a gift by faith, not earned by law. This grounds us in the mystery of grace, hinting at participation in God’s work beyond mere intellectual assent.

verses.text: Is God the God of Jews only? Is He not the God of Gentiles also? Yes, of Gentiles also;
verses.comment: God’s universal plan is for all peoples. This passage underlines the unity and oneness of the faith community, transcending ethnic distinctions—reflective of a visible unified Church.

verses.text: since God is one—He will justify the circumcised by faith and the uncircumcised through that same faith.
verses.comment: Paul affirms the oneness of God and a single means of salvation. This hints at doctrinal unity and a universal communion bound in Christ.

verses.text: Do we then nullify the law by this faith? Absolutely not! On the contrary, we uphold the law.
verses.comment: Faith does not abolish the law, but establishes its true purpose. Christ fulfills and deepens the law—hinting at continuity, tradition, and ongoing transformation in the believing community.
